subject: Re: Java Tools for Extreme Programming [was: Re: [junit] Re:  ANN: "Unit Testing in Java" available]
msgSnippet: ... This is the big reason why I refuse to put any Javadoc in our upcoming book. I think it s a cheap way to extend a book *and* it makes a book out-of-date
messageBody:
>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-06-05 --------------------
>On Wed, 2003-06-04 at 17:13, Curt wrote:
>> Great. I had B&N order one last night so I could look it over. Is
>> there a table of contents available for it somewhere? I checked a
>> handful of sites and the description was a little vague. Just
>> wondering how in-depth it covers JUnit and if it touches on Ant,
>> Cactus, JUnitPref, HttpUnit, etc.
>>
>> Has anyone read "Java Tools for Extreme Programming: Mastering Open
>> Source Tools, including Ant, JUnit, and Cactus"? If so, any
>> opinions? I read through it briefly and it seemed like a good intro
>> book.
>
>I concur with the other Chip's comments... I thought the book was geared
>to beginners. It seemed to me to not be anything more than glorified
>documentation for the different tools, which you can easily get on the
>web.

This is the big reason why I refuse to put any Javadoc in our upcoming book. I think it's a cheap way to extend a book *and* it makes a book out-of-date before it should be.

That is not a personal criticism of any author who has recently put Javadoc in their books. Don't yell at me. It's just my opinion.

Take care.


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
